XL. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any collector shall demand, or receive from any person, any sum of money, under colour of such warrant, after the day that by this a d he is directed to return it to the treasurer, and shall be convicted thereof upon indictment in the court of King's-bench or commission of oyer and terminer, he shall be rendered incapable of being a collcffpr for ever after, and shall suffer imprisonment in the coun^gaol for any time not exceeding one year.

XLI. XLIX. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any overseer or overseers appointed under this act, shall be empowered to die for, raise, and carry away any gravel, stones, sand, or other materials, either in the county of DubEn, or in any adjoining county, which may be wanted for the building, rebuilding, enlarging or repairing of any session-house, gaol, workhouse, bridge, gullet, pipe, or wall, necessary for the support of any road, or for making, repairing, or preserving any road or foot-path in the county of Dublin.

L. Provided however, That it. shall not be lawful for any cverfeer to dig, raise, or carry away, any gravel, stones, fund, or other materials, except such loose gravel or other stones as may be thrown up by the tide from any beach or iea shore, which beach or sea (bore is a publick read, or a bulwark, or defence to any town, ground, or publick road adjoining the same: and that if any person shall be convicted thereof, on the oath of any one credible witness, before any justice of the peace of the county, he shall for ever)' such offence, forfeit the sum of five shillings for every cart-load or car load of such gravel, stones, sand, ot other material io dug, raised, or carried away.

LI. And whereas doubts may arise whether any gravel, stones, sand, or other materials thrown up by the tide, be necessary as a bulwark or defence to any town, ground, or publick road, it shall and may be lawful for any neighbouring justice of the peace, at the request of any overseer, to summon three substantial freeholders of the neighbourhood, to view and determine in the premisses upon oath, and if the majority of them shall find that such gravel, (tones, sand, or other materials are not necessary as a bulwark to any town, ground, or publick road, it fhnl) be lawful for the overseer to make use of the same, without incurring any penalty; and provided, that it shall not be lawful for any overseer to dig for any gravel or stones, or to open any gravel pit or quarry in any deer pari: ., garden, orchard, haggard, or yard, or in the planted avenue, walk, or lawn belonging to any house, without the consent in writing of the owner or occupier, or nearer to the next side of an high road or foot way than fifteen feet, or on the side of any road, so as to make such road dangerous for passengers or carriages; and if any person shall obstruct or prevent any overseer, or the persons employed by any overseer in executing any publick presentment, or in digging for, raising, or carrying away any materials, such as stones, gravel, or sand, that shall be necessary for any publick work, such person shall upon conviction, by the oath of one credible witness, before any justice of the peace of the county, forfeit for every such offence.

LVIII. And whereas notwithstanding the security by recognizance that the persons cle&ed to be treasurers of the county of Dublin, ana their sureties, are by law obliged to enter into, difficulties and delays have arisen and may arise in recovering the publick money on the death, resignation or removal of a treasurer, to the great loss of the county, and the injury, disappointment and distress of the several persons who on being appointed overseers expend their money in executing the preferments of the county: it is necessary to ena&, and be it cuadted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the passing of this act, as often as the present treafufer of the county, or such person who shall at anytime hereafter be eltded treasurer of the county, shall receive from the several collectors of the publick money, or from any of them, a sum or sums of money amounting in the whole to one hundred pounds, he or they shall within three days after the receipt thereof, pay it to the cashier of the governor and company of the bank of Ireland, and shall receive from him a receipt or acknowledgement purporting that he had received such sum to be placed to the account and credit of the county of Dublin, and such

CHAP. XVI.

An Act for facilitating the Trade and Intercourse between this Continued Kingdom and the United States of America. annually.

FQ R facilitating trade and intercourse between this kingdom and the United States of America; belt enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That no manitett, certificate, or other document whatsoever, shall be required for , any ship or vessel belonging to the said United States of America, arriving from thence at any port in this kingdom, or upon entering or clearing out from any port in this kingdom, for any port or place within the said United States, excepting such bonds as are required to be taken duly to export, and not to re-land any goods entitled to a drawback or bounty; any law, ilatute, or cuilom to the contrary notwithstanding.

II. And it is hereby further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in any case where a certificate is required to discharge any such bond entered into for the due landing such goods within the said United States, such bond shall and may be discharged upon a certificate under the hands and seals of aijy officers, who are or may be appointed by the said United States, or any of them for that purpose; and if it shiril happen, that there shall not be any officer so appointed, then and in such case, such bond shall and may be discharged upon a certificate under the hand and seal of any magistrate of the said United "States, or any of them, certifying that there is no such officer at such port or place, and that oath hath been majde before such magistrate by the matter or other person haying the charge of such ship, that the goods for which such certificate is required were duly landed by himVithin the said United States.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all goods, wares, and merchandizes, being the growth or production of any of the United States of America, may be imported directly fiom thence into any of the ports of v this

The twntyfxti Year of George III.

tills kingdom, either in British, Irish, or American (HJjys* by'British or Irish subje&3, or by any of the people inhabiting in and belonging to the said United States, or any' of them, and that the goods, wares, and merchandizes aforesaid, shall and may be entered and landed in any port of this kingdom, upon payment of the same duties as the like articles respectively are or may be subject to, if imported by Irish subjects in Irish ships from any British island in the West Indies, or plantations in America, and no other, notwithstanding such goods, wares, or merchandize, or the ships in which the same may be brought, may not be accompanied with the certificates or other documents heretofore required by law.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That for ships clearing out from any of the poits of this kingdom to any of his Majesty's West Indian idands, which shall take on board any of the articles following, that is to say, rum, sugar, molasses, coffee, cocoa-nuts, ginger, or piamento, to be carried from thence to any part or place within the United States of America, any bonds and securities taken for such ships, shall and may be cancelled and discharged upon the like certificates, as are hereby required to discharge any bonds given in this kingdom for the due landing any other goods in the said United States of America.

V. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all bonds and securities which shall have been taken since the second day of July, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-three, for any ship clearing out for any of his Majesty's West India idands, shall in like manner be cancelled and discharged upon the like certificates as herein before directed.

VI. Provided always, That this act shall continue and be in force until the twenty-fifth day of March, one thousen^ seven hundred and eighty-seven, and no longer.

CHAP. XVII.

ASMa to explain find*nend fin Act haJfiJ in this Kingdom in the eigh h Year of the Rc gn of Her late Myefty Queen Anne, entitled. An act for the better Payment of Inland Bills of Exchange, and malting Premijfory Notes more oh-

ligatory.

WHEREAS by the find ad it is enacted, That for protv fling all inland bills of exchange in this kingdoth, a sum not exceeding two shillings, shall be paid to the public notaries for such protest: and whereas the said payment of two shillings for each protest made payable to the said public notaries by the said act, is inadequate to the trouble attending the same, and fmee the passing the said act, several stamp duties have been imposed, which the publick notaries are obliged to advance, to their manifest loss and inconvenience: and whereas there is not any payment directed by law to be made to them for protesting foreign bills of exchange, or noting bills of exchange: be it therefore enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the several publick notaries of this kingdom, shall be entitled to demand, receive, and recover the sum of four shillings for protesting any foreign bill of exchange whatsoever, and the like sum for protesting any inland bill of exchange, exceeding the amount of twenty pounds; and the sum of two shillings and six pence for protesting any inland bill of exchange, not exceeding the amount of twenty pounds; and the sum of one shilling and six pence for noting any bill of exchange, over ana above all stamp duties which are or shall be payable thereon.

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act shall be deemed, taken, and allowed in all courts of justice in this kingdom, as a publick act, without specially pleading the same.

By Sth Aime, js. was payable on protest ng any inland bill of exchange.

public notaries shall henceforth receive for protesting, as herein.

LXXXIII. And whereas the changing the course of the river commonly called the river Dodder, so as to prevent the same from discharging itself into the said river Anna Liffey and harbour of Dublin, would tend in a very great degree to the improvement of the said harbour, by removing the obflmflion now in the said river Liffey, or harbour, called the bar of Dodder, and for that purpose it is necessary that the said course shall be turned, and the change thereof begin on the northern side of BalPs-bridge, and be carried on and proceed by a cut or canal in such course or direction as to the said corporation shall seem proper, to and upon the south strand below the common high tide mark on the said strand; and in order to preserve the grounds on each side of the said new course from being overflowed in times of flood, and of fpnng tides by making substantial and permanent works or walls on each side of the canal, or cut to be made for such new course of the said river, and to have such works or walls and embankments kept at all times in good repair, so as to prevent any such overflowing: be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it (haS and may be lawful to and for the said corporation upon the terms of compensation a9 herein after mentioned, to cut and open on the north side of BalPs-bridge a sufficient course for the said river Dodder to flow in from the north side of BalPs-bridge, and be carried on and proceed by a cut or canal, in such course or direction as to them shall seem proper, to and upon the said south strand, be! »\ the commit high tide mark on the said strand, of the width of sixty-eight feet at the least in the bottom; and that before the said course shall be turned, the said corporation do, and shall cause to be built at their expence, fufneient walls and embankments on each side of the said new cotirfe, which walls and embankments shall be sufficiently high, to prevent water in said canal at all times from overflowing the adjacent lands, or any of them; and that when such walls and embankments shall be so built and compleated, it shall and tnav be lawful to and for the said corporation to turn, lead, and conduct the course of the said river Dodder into and through the said canal, so that the said river may discharge itself to the southward of the new wall, commonly called the South Wall, and so a3 effectually to prevent the same from discharging itself into the said river or harbour of Dublin.

V. And in order to ascertain tl)e tonnage or burden of all ships or Vessels: be it declared and enacted, That in all cases, where it shall be necessary, by any a d or acts of Parliament made, or hereafter to be made, concerning the revenues of customs or excise, to ascertain the tonnage or burden of any ship or vessel, the rule for admeasuring such ships or vessels shall be as follows, that is to say, the length shall be taken on a straight line along the rabbit of the keel of the ship, from the back of the main stern-post, to a perpendicular b*ne from the for? part of the main stern under the boltfprit, from which substrading three-fifths of the breadth, the remainder shall be esteemed the just length of the keel to find the tonnage 5 and the breadth shall be taken from, the outside of the outside plank in the broadest part of the ship, be it either above or below the main-whales, exclusive of all manner of doubling-planks, that may be wrought upon the fidts of t|ie ship? then multiplying the length of the keel by the breadth so taken, and that pro-dud by half the breadth, and dividing the whole by ninety-four, the quotient shall be deemed the true contents of the tonuage, according to which 1 uk the tonnage of all such flops and vessels shall be measured and ascertained.

XIV. And whereas many frauds are committed to the prejudice*of his Majesty's revenue* in the clandestine run-ping of goods imported, and in relanding certificate goods in this kingdom by water-men and others in boats, wherries, pinnaces, barges, and gallies, which are sometimes rowed with fix, tight, or twelve oars, built on purpose for the smuggling trade, and when they are pursued by officers of the revenue do make their escape: for the preventing whereof, be it further enacted, That from and after the twenty-fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-six, if any boat, wherry, pinnace, barge, or galley rowing, or made or built to row with more than fix oars, shall he found upon the water, or in any barge-house, work-house, (bed, or other place within any port, haven, harbour, or creek in this kingdom, or within four I. agues of the coad thereof, such boat, wherry, pinnace, barge, or galley, with all her tackle and furniture, and the value thereof shall be forfeited, and shall and may be iei/.ed by any officer or officers of his Majesty's revenue, and after the seizure and condemnation of such boat, wherry, pinnace, barge, or galley, the principal officers of his Majesty's reve-

'mic in the port or place where such boat, wherry, pinnace, barge, or galley shall be so condemned, are hereby directed to cause such boat, wherry, pinnace, barge, or galley to be burnt and wholly destroyed.

And whereas by virtue of feveTal laws now of force in this kingdom, persons felling wine, ilrong beer or ale, and brandy, aqua vita, and other spirits by retail, are required to take out licences for these purposes respectively, before they shall respectively fell any wine, strong beer or ale, or spirits: and whereas persons obtaining such licenses* are bound to observe certain rules and regulations with respect of their orderly conduct and behaviour during the time for which such licenses shall be granted: and whereas notwithstanding the laws now erf force to prevent improper persons from obtaining such licenses, fev^ral persons keeping disorderly houses have obtained licenses: therefore be it enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for the commissionera of his Majesty's revenue to refuse to grant any license for selling by retail wine, strong beer or ale, or spirits, or any of them, to any person or persons they shall judge, to be improper persons to be licensed; and that it shall and may be lawful for the said comroissioners, or any three or more of them, by'notice to be published in the Dublin Gazette, to determine and make void all or any licenses which have been or shall have been granted to any person or persons whom they shall think improper to be licensed; and if any person whose license shall be so determined and made void, shall after seven days from the time when such notice shall have been left at the place of abode of such person, fell by retail any of the liquors aforesaid, in respedk whereof, the license or licenses shall have been so determined or made void, every person so felling, shall be subject and liable to the like penalties and forfeitures as are inflicted for felling such liquors, if no license had been granted.

And be it farther enacted, That the inspectors of gaols or prisons to be appointed in pursuance of this act, shall, in their reports of the (late of the respective gaols or prisons under their inspection respectively, insert a copy of the foregoing thirteen regulations at full length, and in a separate column opposite to each of the said regulations, shall certify and (late how far each of them has been observed, and complied with, and shall also state and set dowr? how far the several other directions contained in this present act have been observed and executed.

XXXIV. And whereas the marshalsea prison of the city of Dublin, and the safe custody of such persons as now are or have been therein confined, is and has heretofore been in the marshal of the said city for the time being: and whereas the said marshal from the nature of his office, cannot give that attention to the said marshalsea prison, and to the prisoners who are or shall be confined therein which is required and enjoined by this act, without interfering with the other duties of his said office: be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the pafitng of this act, it shall and may be lawful to and for the corporation of the said city of Dublin, at any quarter afiembly, or at any pofl assembly held for that purpose, to elect and appoint a fit and proper person to be a keeper of said marshalsea prison; and it is hereby declared, That from and after the election of such keeper, and of his taking charge of said prison, the marshal of the said city shall be exempt, and is hereby re^ leased from the care and custody of the prisoners thenceforth to be therein confined; and that said marshal shall not be liable to any damages, cods or charges whatever, for or on ac* eoui£ of any escape that shall be efle&ed or made from said prison.

XXXV. And be it further enacted, That the said keeper shall be answerable for the safe custody of all such prisoners as shall be confined in said marshalsea prison, and that he shall observe arid perform the several and respective duties herein required of other keepers of prisons wherein debtors are confined.

XXVI. CXVI. And whereas the use of narrow wheeled carts, cars, and drays are very injurious to the pavements of this city, and to the highways in and about the neighbourhood thereof: be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no license which has been granted by the.governors of the foundling hospital and work-house to any brewer's dray, or to any cart drawn by one horse, to ply within the city, suburbs, and liberties of Dublin, or within three miles of the same, shall be of any authority to permit any dray or cart drawn by one horse to ply within the said city and liberties, or within three miles of the same, unless the wheels thereof shall be of the breadth of four inches at the lead on the foie, and the dreaks set on with flat-headed bolts, or flat headed nails counterfunk in such a manner as not to rife above the dreak, nor unless the wheels of drays or carts drawn by more than one horse, be of the breadth of seven inches at the lead on the foie, and the dreaks set on as aforesaid } and if to be drawn by more than two horses, unless the wheels be nine inches broad on the foie, and the dreaks let on in like manner; and that no license granted to any car to ply within the said city, suburbs, and liberties, or within three miles thereof, shall be of any authority to permit any car to ply within said city, suburbs, and liberties, or within three miles thereof, unless the wheels thereof be of the breadth of three inches at the lead on the foie, and the dreaks set on as aforementioned; and that every brewer's dray, and every cart or car plying or employed within laid city, suburbs, or liberties, or within three miles thereof, and every private cart, car* or other carriage set up or used by any person or persons redding within the said city, suburbs, or liberties, or within three miles thereof, and employed in the carriage or delivery of goods or commodities, which such person or persons shall have on commission or shall have fold, without having such wheels respectively, shall be considered to all intents and purposes as plying without license, and be subject to, and subject the owners thereof to all the forfeitures or penalties by law enabled against persons plying drays, carts, or cars within said , city, suburbs,

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no action or suit shall be commenced against any person or persons for any thing done in pursuance of this act, until at haft eight days notice shall be thereof given in writing to the secretary to the said directors and commission ecs, nor after three calendar months after the fad committed; and that every such action shall be brought, laid, and tried in the county of the city, or city of Dublin, where such matters and things respectively shall be committed and done; and that the defendant or defendants in such actions and suits may plead the general issue, and give the special matter in evidence on any trial to be had thereon; and if the plaintiff or plaintiffs shall be non-suited or suffer a discontinuance of any such action, or if judgment shall be given for the defendant therein, then and in every such case such defendant or defendants shall have double costs.

CXLVTII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any action or actions shall be brought by said directors and of against any person or pe»--fous, body or bodies politick or corporate whatsoever, for the recovery of any money or monies, penalty or penalties due or forfeited by virtue of this act, and a verdict shall be had and given against such perfoir or persons, body or bodies, he or they shall pay double costs; and the plaintiff or plaintiffs in such action or actions shall have such remedy for the recover)' thcieof, as any plaintiff or plaintiffs may have for his, her, or their costs in any other cases by law.

CXLIX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this net shall he deemed a publick act, and shall be judicially taken notice of as such by all judges, juries, and other persons without specially pleading the lame.

FOR the further prevention of tumtiltucu& risings and assemblies, and for the more adequate and effectual punishment of persons guilty of outrage, riot, and illegal combination, and of administering and taking unlawful oaths: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That if any persons to the number of twelve, or more being unlawfully, riotously and tumultuously assembled, to the disturbance of the publick peace, at any time after the twenty-fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-seven, and being required or commanded, in the King's name, by any one or more justice or justices of tluf peace; or by the sheriff of the county, or his under-sheriff, or by the mayor, sheriff, bailiff or bailiffs, or other head officer or justice of the peace of any city or town corporate, where any such rising or assembly shall be, by proclamation to be made in the King's name, in the form herein after directed, to disperse themselves ?nd depart to their habitations, shall, to the number of twelve or more, not wit lift anding such proclamation made as aforesaid, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously remain or continue together as aforesaid, for the space of one hour after such proclamation made as aforesaid, then such continuing together as aforesaid, to the number of twelve or more, after such proclamation made as aforesaid, shall be adjudged felony, without benefit of clergy; and the offenders therein, being by due course of law thereof convicted, shall be adjudged felons; and shall suffer death as in cases of felony, without benefit of clergy.

CHAP. XXIII.

An Act for the further Increase and Encouragement of Ship* ping and Navigation*

WHEREAS the wealth qqd strength of this kingdom, and the prosperity and safety of every part of the British empire, greatly depend on the encouragement given to shipping and navigation: and whereas by the forty-ninth rule annexed to, and part of an act passed in Ireland, in the fourteenth and fifteenth years of his late Majesty, Charles the second, entitled, An act for settling the subsidy of poundage, and granting a subsidy of tonnage, and other Jttmi of money unto his royal Majesty, his heirs and fuueJfon % the same to be paid upon merchandises imported\ and exported inta^ or out of the kingdom of Ireland, according to a book of rates hereunto annexed: it is dir eft ed that an act passed in England, in the twelfth year of the reign of his said Majesty Charles the second, entitled, dn act for encouraging of Jb'tp* ping and navigation; shall be from time to time duly observed and executed in this kingdom y be it therefore declared qnd enacted by the King's ffloft excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the said recited act passed in England, in the twelfth year of the reign of King Charles the second, and every provision therein contained, so far as the same are not altered or repealed by this act, is and shall be of full force and effect within this kingdom.

II. And whereas it is necessary and highly expedient, that the advantages hitherto given to ships owned and navigated by his Majesty's subjects, Should from henceforth in all cases be confined to {hips wholly built and fitted out in his Majesty's dominions: be it therefore enacted, That from and after the first day of August, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-seven, no ship or vessel foreign built (except such ships or vessels as have been* or shall hereafter be taken by any of his Majesty's {hips or vessels of war, or by any private or other ship or veiled, and condemned at lawful prize in any court of qdjpirtfty) nor any ship or vef-

Africa, or America, which now belong, or at the time of building such ships or reffcls did belong, or which may1 hereafter belong to or be in the possession of his Majesty, his heirs or successors.

XVI. And whereas the officer or officers so appointed t# examine and admeasure such ships and vcficW at aforesaid,

may

may not always be enabled to cause such ship or vcfLl to be. A.D. laid on shore for the purpose of afccriaining her tonnage: 1787.

an<l whereas it would in some cases endanger such Hi ip or Chap. 23. vessel so to do: be it therefore enacted, That in all cases where it may be necessary to ascertain the tonnage of any Method of such ships or vessels when afloat, the following method shallu when be observed, viz. drop a plumb line over the stern of the afl0^t, ship, and measure the distance between such line and the a.rcr part of the ljern port at the load water mark, then measure from the top of the said plumb line in a parallel direction with the water to a perpendicular point immediately over the load water mark at the fore part of the main stern, fubtradting from such measurement the above distance, the remainder w'ifl be the ships extreme length, from which is to be deducted three inches for every foot of the load draught of water for the rake abaft, and also three fifths of the ships breadth for the rake forward, the remainder shall be elleemed the just length of the keel, to find the tonnage and the breadth shall be taken from outside to outside of the plank in the broadest part of the ship, either above or below the main wales- exc'ufive of all manner of flieathing or doubling that may be wrought upon the side of the ship, then multiplying the length of the keel for tonnage by the breadth so taken, and that product by half the breadth, and dividing by ninety-four, the quotient shall be deemed the true contents of the tonnage.

XXXIV. And be it further enacted, That if any ship or vessel which by this act is directed hereafter to be registered, or which is directed (instead of the register now required by law) to take out a new' register according to the form and in the manner herein described, shall arrive at the port to which (he belongs, at the expiration of the time assigned in the notice herein directed, such ship or vessel shall not be permitted to clear outwards to foreign parts, or coastways, or to proceed to sea in order to fish on the coast, or for any other purpose whatever, as a British or Irish ship or vessel, nor shall be in any wise entitled to the privileges of a British or Irish ship or vessel, unless the owner or owners thereof shall have obtained a certificate, according to the form, and in the manner by this act described and directed; and in case any- such ship or vessel shall depart from such port without being registered, and without having obtained a certificate as aforesaid, every such ship or vessel shall be subject to forfeiture, together with all the guns, furniture, ammunition, tackle, and apparel to such ship or vessel belonging.

XXXVIII. And be it further enacted, That in lieu of all fees and perquisites now payable to any person or persons, on the registry of any ship or vessel so built, before the first day of May, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-seven, there shall be paid, on the first registry of every ship or vessel which shall be registered purftiant to this act, the following sums, by-way of fees or perquisites, and no more, that is to say, by all ships or vessels decked, or of the burthen of fifteen tons, and not exceeding fifty tons, the sum of one shilling and six-pence, and no more, and by all ships or vessels exceeding fifty tons, and not exceeding oue hundred tons, the sum of two shillings and six pence, and no more, and by all ships or vessels exceeding one hundred tons, and not exceeding two hundred tons, the sum of three ^hillings and six pence, and no more, and by all ships or vessels exceeding two hundred tons, the sum of five shillings, and no more, which several sums shall be payable to such officers respectively, in the same shares and proportions in which the sums now payable are distributed, and that the like fees and perquisites respectively shall be paid upon the registry of, or transfer of property in any ship or vessel, after the same shall have been registered in manner herein directed.

XXXIX. And be it further enacted, That if any person or persons authorized and required by this act, in respect of his or their office or offices, to perform any act or thing directed and required to be done or personped, pursuant to any of the provisions of this act, shall wilfully neglect or refuse to do or perform the same, according so the true intent and meaning of this act, every such person so neglecting or refusing shall, on being duly convicted thereof, forfeit the sum of five hundred pounds to his Majesty, hi*3 heirs and successors, and for the second offence shall forfeit in like manner the sum of five hundred pounds to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, and shall from thenceforth be rendered incapable of serving his Majesty in any office or employment relative to the revenue, or in any civil capacity whatever.

XL. And be it further enacted, That if any person or persons shall knowingly and wilfully, falsely make oath to any of the matters herein required to be so verified, such

CHAP. XXVII.

An Act to prevent the forging, fellings or otherwise improper// disposing of Mediterranean Passes.

WHEREAS in conformity to certain treaties between his Majesty and the several dates and governments of Barbary, passes of a certain form are to be granted, under the hand and seal of the lord high admiral of Great Britain and Ireland, or of the of for executing the office of lord high admiral of Great Britain and Ireland for the time being, and such passes have, from time to time, been issued under certain rules and regulations, and are commonly called Mediterranean passes: and whereas it is necessary, to the due observance of the treaties aforesaid, that the passes, commonly called Mediterranean passes, Should not be sold, or otherwise improperly disposed or made use of by persons obtaining the same, and Should not be forged or counterfeited, or in any manner obliterated, altered or falsified; and whereas the offences of counterfeiting, erasing, and altering such passes, being frequently committed in foreign parts, are not triable or cognizable in any court of Ireland; be it therefore enacted by the King* most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this Persons ob- present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the tuning Medi- same. That no pass, called a Mediterranean pass, shall be terranean passes, issued to the mailer of any ship or vessel belonging to hia to give bonds Majesty's subjects of Ireland, unless such matter, with two as herein. sufficient sureties or the owner or owners of such ship or vessel, or any two of them, shall have given bond to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, in the sum of five hundred pounds, if such ship or vessel be under the burthen of one hundred tons, and in the sum of two hundred pounds* if such ship or vessel be of the burthen of one hundred tons or more, conditioned that such matter cl fuel) fLp cr \e£-fel, or any person who shall succeed him as matter cf such ship or vessel, shall not dispose of, or fell or lend such pass to any person, or otherwise suffer the same to be made use of for the benefit or protection of any other ship or vessel, as also conditioned that such matter, or in case of his death or inability, the person who shall succeed him as aforesaid, shall after his return to this kingdom, on £he demand of the chief officer of any port in this kingdom, deliver such pass tp such officer.

CHAP. XXXIV.

An Act to prevent the Stealing of Dogs.

WHEREAS the practice of dealing dogs has encreaf* ^cra>u» w«u ed> for remedy whereof, be it enacted by the

ftad any* dog" King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and dec. forfeit 10I consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and b/'^he authority of the same, That if any person shall, from and after the passing of this act, deal any dog or dogs of any kind or fort whatsoever, from the owner or owners thereof, or from any person or persons intruded by the owner or owneqpthereof* with such dog or dogs, or shall fell, buy, receive, harbour, detain or keep any dog or dogs of any kind or fort whatsoever, knowing the same to have been doleo as aforesaid, every such person upon being thereof lawfully convicted before one or more judice or justices of the peace of the county, county of the city, or county of the town or place corporate, wherein such offence or offences shall be committedt or before the justices at the general quarter sessions of the peace, or any adjournment thereof, who are hereby authorized and directed summarily and finally to hear and determine the same Upon the confession of the party, or upon the oath of one or more person or persons, which oath the said justices are hereby empowered to administer, shall be punish-cd by fine not exceeding ten pounds, and in case such fine er imprisoned shall not be paid, shall be imprisoned for any time not ex- month. ceeding one month.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid,

fence 201. That ii any such person or persons so convicted, shall com-

perron or persons {o offending, and being thereof lawfully Convicted shall be fined a sum not exceeding twenty pounds, and in case such fine shall not be paid, shall be imprisoned for any time not exceeding three months

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if such person or persons so convicted, shall commit any of the offences aforesaid a third time, every such person or persons so offending being thereof lawfully convicted, shall be committed to the house of industry, or house of correction, there to be kept to hard labour, for any time not exceeding six months#

IV. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons by day or by night, wilfully and unlawfully take and carry away, or poison or destroy any mastiff or other dog, every such person being thereof convicted before one or more just ice or justices of the peace for the county, city, or county of of a city, or town corporate, such offender or offenders, shall be committed to the house of correction of such county, city, or place, for three months.

V. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for any one or more of his Majesty*9 justices of the peace in, or for any cotinty, division or place, upon information to him or them made for that purpose, to grant a warrant or warrants, to search for any dog or dogs stolen as aforesaid, and in case any such dog or dogs, or the skin or /kins of such dog or dogs, shall upon search be found, to take and restore every such dog or dogs,

jor such skin or skins to the owner thereof, and the person or persons in whose custody or possession any such dog or dogs, /kin or skins shall be found (in case it shall appear that such person was privy to such dog or dogs having been stolen as aforesaid, or that such skin or skins was or were the stein or skins of any dog or dogs stolen as aforesaid, ) shall respectively be subject and liable to the like penalties and punishments as persons convicted of dealing any dog or dogs, are herein before made subject and liable to.

VI. Provided always, That this act shall not be deemed or construed to extend to abridge the privilege of lords of manors.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the twenty-third and twenty-fourth years of the reign of his present Majesty, entitled, An act for ascertaining the qualification of fufh persons as shall tahe out comm 'tssions of the peace for counties at large; certain qualifications are required to entitle any person to exercise the office of a justice of the peace within such countiesin this kingdom: and whereas itisneceflary tore-peal the said act, and it maybe expedient to issue newcommissi* oners of the peace for the several counties at large in this kingdom: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the said recited act, and every clause, matter, and thing therein contained, be, and the same is, and are herehy repealed and tnade void.

II. And in case it shall be thought proper to issue new Commissions of the peace for any such county: be it further enacted, That no perfoo named or appointed a justice of the peace in any such new commission, who shall have been named or appointed a justice of the peace in any such former commission, and shall have taken the oath of office of a justice of the peace, and performed the other requisites preferi-bed by law to qualify himselffor executing the same, shall be obliged again to take such oath of office, or perform the other requisites prescribed by law, in order to qualify himself to execute the same, but every such person so re appointed, shall, and he is hereby enabled to execute the office of a justice of the peace -in every such county in which he shall be so re-appointed, without again taking such oath of office, or again performing any other such requisite, any law to the contrary notwithstanding; nor shall any such person so re-ap- pointed, be charged with, or pay any fee ^rhatsoever, for or on account of any fuckjiew commission.

III. And for the better execution of the law and for preserving the peace in this kingdom: be it enacted, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the lord lieutenant, or other chief governor or governors of this kingdom for the time being, by and with the advice of the privy council, to divide such of the several counties at large of this kingdom as they shall think fit, into such number of distritls as to them shall seem meet for the purposes of this and none other; every such district to consist of a barony, half barony, or such number of baronies or half baronies within the said counties respectively, as the lord lieutenant, or other chief governor or governors aforesaid for the time being, by and with the advice of the privy council, shall appoint, and every such distri£l shall be distinguished by the name of some one barony or half barony of which it shall be composed.

IV. And be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the lord lieutenant, or other chief governor or governors aforesaid, from time to time to nominate and appoint one principal peace officer in each such district respectively; such principal peace officer to be called chief con-liable of such district, and that the grand jury of each county at large, at the assizes, shall from time to time nominate and appoint sixteen proper persons, being protestants, to act as sub-constables within every such district; such sub-constables to be in lieu and in the place of all sub-constables appointed, or to be appointed by such grand juries for baronies or hz\if baronies, according to the laws now of force; and all such sub-constables to be appointed by virtue of this act as aforp-said, shall at all times be aiding and assisting -in preserving the peacej and executing the law within every such district, and shall obey such lawful directions as they shall from time to time receive from any magistrate of the county wherein such district shall lie, or from the chief constable of such district; and the said chief constable shall in like manner obey such lawful directions as he shall from time to time receive from any such magistrate as aforesaid^ for the preservation of the peace, and a due execution of the law; and if any of the aforesaid persons shall neglect or refuse so to obey as aforesaid, he or they shall be liable to such penalty not exceeding forty, shillings, to be levied by distrefe and sale of the goods of the party, by order of the justices at the next feffi-ons of the peace for such county, and such imprisonment in the common gaol, not exceeding one oj^pth. as the said justices after examination and proof upon oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses, or the confession of the party, shall iinpose and direct.

An Act for amending and making perpetual an Ady entitled. An Act for buying andfelling all Sorts of Com and Meal, and other Things therein mentioned, by Weighty and for the more effectual preventing of Frauds committed in the buying and selling thereof

WHEREAS by an act made in the fourth year of Aa*-her late Majesty Queen Anne, entitled, An act for the regulating the weights used in this kingdom, and that salt mnd meal shall be sold by weight: it is enacted, That in every city, borough, and market-town, within this kingdom, there shall be appointed by the chief magistrate (except in places where the tolls and customs belong to any other person) and in all such places by the person or persons to whom the tolls and customs belong, an honest and discreet person to be weigh-master, to weigh all goods between buyer and feller, and such chief magistrate or persons to jvhom the tolls and customs belong, are thereby required, under certain penalties therein mentioned, to provide such weigh-master with just balances and weights to weigh all manner of goods: and whereas by an act passed in this kingdom in the twenty-fifth year of his late Majesty King George the second, entitled.

An act for buying and selling all fort of corny mealy and other things therein mentioned, by weight, and for the more effectual preventing of frauds committed in the buying and selling thereof; which said last mentioned act hath been continued by several ft 8 pasted fmee the making thereof, and particularly hath by an act passed in the twenty-first and twenty-second years of his present Majesty, entitled. An act for reviving, continuing and amending several temporary Statutes; been continued to the twenty-fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-seven, and to the end of the then next session of Parliament: and whereas the said act hath been by long experience found very beneficial to his Majesty's subjects, and is fit to be made perpetual: be it therefore enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the said last mentioned act be, and the same h hereby made perpetual.

II. And whereas the said act recites, that great abufo arise by private persons keeping scales for weighing goods for hire and price, to the injury of the lawful and estabHihed weigh-master, and to the abuse of the publick in general, to prevent winch the said act subjects the persons who shall keep such private scales to certain penalties, and has made provision for enforcing such penalties befoae the chief magistrates of the towns in which Inch scales are used, but no power is given to any person to convict of such offences, or enforce such penalties wluie the offence is committed in a market-town, not bfcing corporate, or having a chief magistrate, whereby private persons are in such towns greatly encouraged to keep such scales, to the injury of the owners of tolls and cu(tom8, who in such towns are by the said first recited act, compelled under heavy penalties to appoint weigh-raaf-ters, and provide weights and measures in such towns: to remedy which, be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every person who shall for hire or price, either in money, drink, or other gratuity, in any market-town in which there shall be a weigli-master duly appointed by the owner of the tolls and customs of such market, and duly provided with scales and measure3, weigh at any such private scales any corn or grain, hides, tallow, meal, potatoes, or other goods exposed to sale in the market, not being his Or her own goods or property, shall for every draught by him or her so weigh ft, forfeit the sum of two (hilling? and six pence, to be paid the informer, which forfeiture in every such market-town, not being a town — corporate, shall he recovered before any justice of the peace of the county in which such town is situate, upon the confession of the parties, or upon the oath of one or more witnesses, and upon conviction such forfeiture shall be levied by warrant', under the hand and seal of such judice of vhc peace, by distress and sale of the offender's goods.

An Act to continue and amend an act, entitled, Ana3 for repairing the road leading from the town of Nt*wcastle in the county of Limerick, to the city of Limerick, and from thence to the city of Cork, was amended and further continued: and whereas the said last mentioned act will expire at the end of the present session of Parliament, but the same being found of general use, ought to be contiuu-ed: be it therefore enacted by the king's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the said act shall continue and be in force for the term of two years from the twenty-fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-eight, and to the end of the then session of Parliament, and no longer.

And whereas there are a variety of offences dated in said recited act, and also in this present act, for which pawn-brokers and audioneers are finable; be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no fine whatever shall be determined or adjudged against any pawn-broker or audioneer, until such pawn-broker or audioneer shall be duly summoned to appeal before the judice or judices, before whom complaint* of any of said offences shall be made, and that such reasonable time shall be allowed for the atten* dance of such pawn broker or audioneer, as the special case shall require, the service of every such summons to be proved on the oath of one credible witness no way intended in the event of such adjudication.

XXIII. And be it further enacted by the authority, aforesaid. That the several and respective clauses, natters, and articles in this act contained, shall be in force immedi«, ately after the same shall receive the royal affect, and also, that all the clauses, matters, and articles contained in said recited act, which are not specially repealed, altered, on amended by this present act, shall be, and they are respectively hereby declared to be in as full force as if this act had, not been made. t

XXIV. And be it further enacted by the authority* aforesaid, That this act shall be deemed and considered as?, publick act, and shall be judicially taken notice of as fqchj. without the f?me being specially pleaded.
